steps.title: Clean off dust and grime with a soft bristle brush.
steps.content: Clean off dust and grime with a soft bristle brush. Before removing corrosion, you need to clean off any dust or grime on top of it. Use a nonabrasive cleaner, like regular dishwashing soap.

steps.title: Boil off caked on food.
steps.content: Boil off caked on food. To get out burnt food on the bottom of your pots without damaging them, fill the pot with a couple inches of water. Put it on heat and allow it to reach a boil and leave it there for about 10 minutes. Afterward, remove it from the heat and use a wooden spatula to pull up the food, which should have been loosened up. Repeat this until the pot is clean. Refrain from using steel wool or Brillo Pads to pick up caked on food, because they can scratch up the pot and make it harder to clean in the future.

steps.title: Boil vinegar or lemon juice in the pot.
steps.content: Boil vinegar or lemon juice in the pot. To remove oxidation, mix water and either vinegar or lemon juice in a pot. Turn on the heat and allow the mixture to cook for fifteen minutes after it hits a hard boil. Throw small aluminum cookware in the pot so that they can be treated as well. Repeat as necessary. The mixture should be about two tablespoons of lemon juice or vinegar for every quart of water.

steps.title: Rinse and dry the pot well.
steps.content: Rinse and dry the pot well. Run warm water over the cookware to carefully remove any residue of the lemon juice or vinegar. Then wipe it down with a rag to dry it off.

steps.title: Clean the surface with a soft bristle brush.
steps.content: Clean the surface with a soft bristle brush. Clean off dirt with a soft bristle brush. Try to remove all dust and large particles with the brush.

steps.title: Wipe it down with dishwashing detergent and a sponge.
steps.content: Wipe it down with dishwashing detergent and a sponge. Apply water and dishwashing detergent to a sponge. Use moderate pressure when wiping down the surface. Sometimes, this will be sufficient to remove oxidation.

steps.title: Scrub with a lemon.
steps.content: Scrub with a lemon. If detergent did not remove the oxidation, try a lemon. Cut the lemon in half and place salt on the inside. Then rub the surface down with the inside of the lemon, so that the salt and acid of the lemon can remove aluminum oxide. Rub gently because the salt is abrasive. Alternatively, you can apply lemon juice and salt to a rag and use the rag to gently rub the aluminum.

steps.title: Use aluminum etching cleaner for hard to remove oxidation.
steps.content: Use aluminum etching cleaner for hard to remove oxidation. For hard to remove oxidation, apply aluminum etching cleaner to stainless steel wool, grade 0000 to 000. Put on gloves and rub problem spots with the cleaner. Rub as gently as possible to remove corrosion.

steps.title: Rinse the aluminum off with a clean sponge.
steps.content: Rinse the aluminum off with a clean sponge. Do not allow detergent, lemon, or other cleaners to dry on the surface. Use another wet sponge, without detergent, to wipe it down, removing the soap.

steps.title: Watch for cracks in the paint.
steps.content: Watch for cracks in the paint. Paint prevents the formation of aluminum oxide, which can be unattractive, but prevents poultice corrosion. When the paint begins to crack on aluminum surfaces often exposed to water, poultice corrosion forms, eating away at the aluminum. [1] X Research source Poultice corrosion will appear as either a white powder or a white goo.

steps.title: Remove paint chips.
steps.content: Remove paint chips. Where the paint has begun to crack, scrape off paint from that area. You can use a putty knife to get under the paint and lift it up. [2] X Research source For larger areas, use 220-grit sandpaper to sand off the paint. Create a gradual transition along the edges between the painted area and the bare metal.

steps.title: Use general purpose adhesive remover to de-wax the surface.
steps.content: Use general purpose adhesive remover to de-wax the surface. Apply the adhesive remover to a rag. Use the rag to wipe down the area where you have scraped off the paint. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Apply an epoxy paint.
steps.content: Apply an epoxy paint. Find an epoxy paint that closely matches the paint on the surrounding area. Use a brush to apply a couple of coats of paint, so that there is a thick layer. There is no need to apply primer to a small spot before painting it. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Apply sealant around hardware.
steps.content: Apply sealant around hardware. Movable hardware like fasteners and spreaders often rip up surrounding paint when they move. Thus, new paint jobs around the area usually wonâ€™t last long. Instead, apply a low-adhesion polyurethane or polysulfide sealant around the hardware base. Seal up the entire circumference of the hardware base, so that no paint can seep down to the aluminium. [5] X Research source
